front.title: Proof of Process: An Evidence Framework for Digital Authorship Attestation

abstract.t: This document defines the Proof of Process (PoP) protocol, an evidence framework built on the IETF RATS architecture (RFC 9334) that enables tamper-evident, independently verifiable attestation of how digital content is produced. Rather than analyzing finished outputs, PoP captures cryptographically sealed behavioral evidence during the creation process, binding it to elapsed time through Verifiable Delay Functions and to device identity through hardware attestation.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The proliferation of AI-generated content has created an urgent need for mechanisms that can attest to the human authorship process of digital works. Current approaches such as watermarking and AI-detection classifiers operate on the finished output and are increasingly unreliable as generative models improve.

This document specifies the Proof of Process (PoP) protocol, which takes a fundamentally different approach: rather than analyzing finished content, it captures tamper-evident evidence of the creation process itself. The framework builds on the IETF RATS architecture and defines roles, evidence formats, and verification procedures for process-based authorship attestation.

The key insight is that human authorship exhibits measurable behavioral characteristics -- typing cadence, revision patterns, pause distributions, error-correction sequences -- that are computationally expensive to fabricate in real time. By binding these behavioral observations to cryptographic time proofs, the framework creates evidence that is both tamper-evident and temporally authentic.

section.title: Conventions and Definitions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Jitter Seal Mechanism
section.t: The jitter seal binds evidence packets to the physical timing characteristics of the authorship environment, creating a non-transferable proof of temporal authenticity.

The Attester captures inter-keystroke timing intervals at microsecond resolution. These intervals exhibit natural jitter from human motor control that serves as a behavioral entropy source. The jitter seal is computed as:
seal = HMAC-SHA-256(device_key, timing_vector || T_difficulty || nonce)
where T_difficulty is the VDF difficulty parameter that determines the minimum wall-clock time required to produce the seal.

section.title: Verifiable Delay Function Mechanisms
section.t: The Proof of Process framework employs Verifiable Delay Functions (VDFs) to bind evidence to elapsed wall-clock time. A VDF is a function that requires a prescribed number of sequential computation steps to evaluate, but whose output can be efficiently verified.
This document specifies the use of repeated squaring in an RSA group as the VDF primitive:
y = x^(2^T_difficulty) mod N
where x is derived from the evidence packet hash, T_difficulty controls the time parameter, and N is an RSA modulus from a trusted setup.

section.title: Continuation Tokens
section.t: A continuation token provides cryptographic linkage between evidence collection sessions for the same document. This enables the Verifier to assess the complete authorship timeline even when the Attester's collection process spans multiple sessions.

section.title: Absence Proofs
section.t: An absence proof demonstrates that no valid evidence chain exists for a claimed authorship period, supporting the detection of fabricated provenance claims.

section.title: Forgery Cost Bounds
section.t: The total cost of forging an evidence chain of duration D with n evidence packets is bounded by:
C_total = C_vdf(n, T_difficulty) + C_entropy(n) + C_hardware

section.title: Collaborative Authorship
section.t: When multiple authors contribute to a single document, the Proof of Process framework MUST maintain distinct evidence chains for each contributor while enabling a unified verification of the composite work.

section.title: Trust Policies
section.t: The Relying Party evaluates Attestation Results against locally configured trust policies. Four assurance tiers are defined (T1-T4), each requiring progressively stronger evidence.

section.title: Privacy Considerations
section.t: The Proof of Process framework collects behavioral evidence during content creation. Evidence packets MUST be constructed using the principle of data minimization as defined in .

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The security of the Proof of Process framework depends on several assumptions about the Attester's operating environment and the cryptographic primitives employed.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document requests registration of the media type application/pop-evidence+cbor and a COSE header parameter pop-chain-ref.

section.title: Integration Guide
section.t: This appendix provides guidance for integrating the Proof of Process framework with existing content management systems.
